    Introduction to tenm package

Function to clean duplicated longitude and latitude data

Source: R/clean_dup.R
clean_dup.Rd

Clean up duplicated or redundant occurrence records that present overlapping longitude and latitude geographical coordinates regarding a referent system that the user can choose from fourth possible ways to eliminate: distance threshold, per single pixel grain of resolution, by pixel neighborhood, or both combined distance and pixel at the same time.This function has as its main purpose to eliminate occurrence points geographically spliced, using the information of the spatial position to determine it, in order to debug large clouds of occurrence points that could cause an environmental overestimation in the future model, we call this process "cleaning of spatial duplicated data". The user has to set a distance in "units" that arose an overlapping area from a random chosen record where any other occurrence within this is consider as a duplicated and then eliminated. Also you can use a raster mask with a determinate pixel grain resolution as a base sift; see in arguments raster_mask and n_ngbs.

Usage

clean_dup(
  data,
  longitude,
  latitude,
  threshold = 0,
  by_mask = FALSE,
  raster_mask = NULL,
  n_ngbs = 0
)

Arguments

data

A data.frame with longitude and latitude of occurrence records belongings to some specie.

longitude

A character vector of the column name "longitude" within the dataframe.

latitude

A character vector of the column name of "latitude" within the dataframe.

threshold

A numeric value representing the euclidean distance between coordinates to be considered as a duplicate. Also it could be view as a value of radio (r) that covers an area.

by_mask

Logical. If TRUE the elimination of duplicates will be done using a raster layer as a mask; If False the elimination of duplicates will be done by the distance threshold.

raster_mask

An object of class SpatRaster that will be used to clean duplicates that are present in the same ID pixel.

n_ngbs

Number of pixel neighbors. Remove duplicates depending on how many pixels range you want, 1 is for eliminate duplicates in the same pixel, that means just one record per single pixel of resolution,2 is a neighborhood with one-pixel length of 3 for 3 pixels, 3 is an 5 for 5 vicinity and so on depending on how much area you want to cover.

Value

Returns a data.frame with coordinate data from a species

Examples

data(abronia)
tempora_layers_dir <- system.file("extdata/bio",package = "tenm")
tenm_mask <- terra::rast(file.path(tempora_layers_dir,"1939/bio_01.tif"))
# Clean duplicates without raster mask (just by distance threshold)
# First check the number of occurrence records
print(nrow(abronia))
#> [1] 106
# Clean duplicated records using a distance of ~ 18 km (0.1666667 grades)
ab_1 <- tenm::clean_dup(data =abronia,
                        longitude = "decimalLongitude",
                        latitude = "decimalLatitude",
                        threshold = terra::res(tenm_mask),
                        by_mask = FALSE,
                        raster_mask = NULL)
# Check number of records
print(nrow(ab_1))
#> [1] 10
# Clean duplicates using a raster mask
ab_2 <- tenm::clean_dup(data =abronia,
                        longitude = "decimalLongitude",
                        latitude = "decimalLatitude",
                        threshold = terra::res(tenm_mask)[1],
                        by_mask = TRUE,
                        raster_mask = tenm_mask,
                        n_ngbs = 1)
# Check number of records
print(nrow(ab_2))
#> [1] 9
